{
  "article_text": [
    "several proposals for scalable solid - state quantum computers have been recently published @xcite .",
    "the simulation of quantum information processing with a large number of qubits will be necessary to test these computers .",
    "we show in this paper how to implement the control not ( cn ) gate between remote qubits in a spin chain using a sequence of electromagnetic pulses .",
    "the errors generated by non - resonant effects are estimated analytically and computed numerically .",
    "we give the probability of error as a function of the rabi frequency and the number of qubits .",
    "the two - level approximation for an individual transition used in this paper for analysis of the system ( see also ref . [ 4 ] ) allows one to simulate the quantum dynamics in a system with an enormous number ( @xmath0 , where @xmath1 is the number of qubits ) of quantum states .",
    "this technique is based on selection of states generated as a result of the resonant or near - resonant transitions , while other transitions are neglected .    in sec .",
    "i we give the hamiltonian of the nuclear spin quantum computer . in sec .",
    "ii we use the resonance approximation to show that each quantum state interacts resonantly only with a single state .",
    "this allows us to decrease from exponential in @xmath1 to polynomial in @xmath1 the number of differential equations in the system . in sec .",
    "iii we use the solution of the problem in the resonance approximation to estimate error probabilities in the implementation of a cn gate caused by finite detuning from exact resonance .",
    "we consider a chain of identical nuclear spins placed in a nonuniform high external magnetic field @xmath2 , with a uniform gradient .",
    "the nuclear magnetic resonance ( nmr ) frequency for the @xmath3th spin is @xmath4 , where @xmath5 is the nuclear gyromagnetic ratio and @xmath6 is the @xmath7-component of the magnetic field at the location of the @xmath3th spin .",
    "the gradient of the magnetic field ( in the direction of the chain ) provides a shift of @xmath8 by the value @xmath9 between the neighboring spins .",
    "( for the physical parameters see ref .  [ 4 ] . )",
    "the hamiltonian of the spin chain in an external radio - frequency ( rf ) field is , @xmath10 where @xmath11 is the ising interaction constant and @xmath12 is the operator of the @xmath7-component of spin @xmath13 .",
    "the operator , @xmath14 , describing the interaction of spins with the _ rf _ pulses , can be written in the form , @xcite @xmath15 + @xmath16,$ ] where @xmath17 , @xmath18 and @xmath19 are the rabi frequency , the frequency and the phase of the @xmath20th pulse ; @xmath21 .",
    "each quantum state of the spin chain can be described as a superposition of eigenstates of @xmath22 , for example , @xmath23 and so on , where the state @xmath24 corresponds to the direction of the @xmath3th nuclear spin along the direction of the magnetic field ( spin up ) , and the state @xmath25 corresponds to the spin being in the opposite direction ( spin down ) .",
    "the wave function , @xmath26 , of the spin chain can be written in the interaction representation as a linear combination of the individual states , @xmath27 where @xmath28 is the energy of the state @xmath29 .",
    "the contribution of each quantum state to the wave function , @xmath30 , is given by the coefficient @xmath31 .",
    "the quantity @xmath32 is the probability of finding the spin chain in the state @xmath29 at time @xmath33 .    the schrdinger equation for the coefficients @xmath31 has the form ( we put @xmath34 ) , @xmath35c_m(t ) , $ ] where @xmath36 for @xmath37 and @xmath38 , respectively .",
    "@xmath39 for the states @xmath29 and @xmath40 connected by a single - spin transition .",
    "@xmath41 for all other states .",
    "the schrdinger equation can be numerically integrated only for a spin chain with small enough number of spins since the number of states increases exponentially with @xmath1 .",
    "the problem can be simplified when the rabi frequency , @xmath17 , is much less than the difference , @xmath9 , between the nmr frequencies of the neighboring spins , @xmath42 .",
    "suppose that a pulse is resonant with the @xmath3th spin in the chain , @xmath43 .",
    "then one can admit that this pulse affects in some approximation only the @xmath3th spin in the chain and does not interact with other spins . in this case , only the term with the energy @xmath44 effectively contributes to the right - hand side of the schrdinger equation , so that the states @xmath45 and @xmath29 are connected by a single - spin flip of the @xmath3th spin . in this case , we reduce the schrdinger equation to the set of two differential equations , @xmath46c_m(t),\\ ] ] @xmath47c_p(t),\\ ] ] where @xmath37 , and @xmath29 and @xmath40 are two stationary states which are connected by a single - spin transition of the @xmath3th spin , @xmath43 .    the solution of eq .",
    "( [ sch1 ] ) , for initial conditions , @xmath48 , after the action of the @xmath20th pulse has the form , @xmath49 e^{\\left({-i\\tau_n\\delta_n\\over 2}\\right)},\\ ] ] @xmath50 where @xmath51 and @xmath52 are the beginning and the and of the @xmath20th pulse , @xmath53 is the duration of the @xmath20th pulse , @xmath54 ( we do not indicate the dependence of @xmath55 on the indices @xmath56 and @xmath57 ) , @xmath58 is the precession frequency in the frame rotating with the frequency @xmath18 .",
    "suppose that at @xmath51 the system was in the state @xmath40 . in the case of the exact resonance ( @xmath59 ) and for @xmath60 ( a @xmath61 pulse ) eqs .",
    "( [ map ] ) describe the resonant transition from the state @xmath40 to the state @xmath29 . if the frequency of the next pulse also satisfies the resonance condition , @xmath62 , then the system with probability equal to unity will transform to the state @xmath63 , and so on .",
    "the advantages given by the two - level approximation described above are obvious : ( a ) we solve the problem by using the discrete map ( [ map ] ) instead of integrating differential equations ; ( b ) we can consider only the states with large enough probabilities and neglect all other states in a controlled way ; ( c ) we can estimate errors caused by non - resonant effects and minimize them by choosing optimal parameters .    in this paper we will estimate the error in implementation of a unitary operation for remote qubits ( which is a particular case of the well - known control - not ( cn ) gate ) using a sequence of @xmath61-pulses .",
    "this cn gate is defined as the unitary operator , @xmath64 , with the following properties :    @xmath65    @xmath66    where @xmath67 and @xmath68 are known phases .",
    "the target qubit ( @xmath69 ) should change its state only when the control qubit ( @xmath70 ) is in the state @xmath71 .",
    "the operator , @xmath64 , can be used to create an entangled state for remote qubits : @xmath72 . to accomplish the ( 4b ) operation in the system described by the hamiltonian ( 1 ) , we choose a sequence of @xmath61-pulses with resonant frequencies ( for which all @xmath59 ) . in this case",
    ", the state @xmath73 transforms to the state @xmath74 , with probability equal to unity , by the following scheme : @xmath75 @xmath76 the sequence of pulses which realizes this protocol has the following form : @xmath77 , @xmath78 , @xmath79 , @xmath80 ,  ,",
    "@xmath81 , @xmath82 .",
    "if we apply the same protocol to the state @xmath83 , then with some probability the system will remain in this state because all transitions are non - resonant with the detuning @xmath84 . since @xmath85 these non - resonant transitions have the probabilities ( see eq .",
    "( [ map ] ) ) , @xmath86    in this paper we study the errors generated during the operation ( [ u1 ] ) under the condition that the transitions in eq .",
    "( [ u2 ] ) are resonant .",
    "the operator @xmath64 in eqs .",
    "( [ u1 ] ) and ( [ u2 ] ) can be written as a product , @xmath87 , of operators of individual pulses @xmath88 , where @xmath89 .",
    "we take the rabi frequency to be the same , @xmath90 , for all pulses .",
    "then the error , @xmath91 , generated by the @xmath20th pulse is defined only by the detuning , @xmath55 .",
    "the values of detuning , @xmath92 , are the same for all pulses , @xmath93 , except for the third pulse , where @xmath94 .",
    "we denote @xmath95 for @xmath96 and @xmath97 .",
    "each unwanted state generated by the @xmath20th pulse can produce other unwanted states under the action of the other @xmath98 pulses .",
    "this causes the generation of a hierarchy of different states . instead of one ground state , which should be the result of ( 4a )",
    ", we generate a series of different unwanted states .",
    "since the dynamics is generated by the discrete map ( [ map ] ) , probability of error can be estimated analytically .",
    "suppose that we can measure only the states with probability @xmath99 , where @xmath100 can be defined by the experimental conditions .",
    "then , if @xmath101 , we shall not find in the system any unwanted states and the cn gate is realized with probability equal to unity . in fig .  1",
    ", we plot @xmath102 ( solid line ) and @xmath103 ( dotted line ) as functions of @xmath104 .",
    "we suppose that @xmath105 .",
    "one can see from fig .  1 that @xmath106 and @xmath107 are less than @xmath108 only in very narrow regions of the values of @xmath104 ( in the vicinity of @xmath109 , @xmath110 @xcite ) .",
    "hence , high precision is required to implement the cn gate , ( [ u1 ] ) , ( [ u2 ] ) , without error .",
    "let us consider now in detail the case of arbitrary @xmath102 : @xmath111 , and explain how the errors can be estimated analytically in the operation ( [ u1 ] ) .",
    "the first pulse @xmath112 generates one unwanted state @xmath113 with the probability @xmath102 .",
    "the probability to remain in the ground state is @xmath114 .",
    "the second pulse , @xmath115 , generates an additional unwanted state from the ground state , @xmath116 , with probability @xmath117 , and transforms the state @xmath118 to the state @xmath119 without generating additional states , since the second pulse is resonant to this transition .",
    "the probability of remaining in the ground state is now @xmath120 .",
    "the total number of states after the action of two pulses is three .",
    "the probabilities of all generated states after the action of the @xmath121 pulse are :    [ tab ] @xmath122 : = @xmath123 , + @xmath118 : @xmath124 , + @xmath125 : @xmath126 , + @xmath119 : @xmath127 .",
    "( note , that above expressions can be considered only as estimates because we estimated probabilities instead of complex amplitudes . ) one can continue to calculate the states generated by subsequent pulses and estimate their probabilities in a similar way .",
    "however , for @xmath128 , one can omit the contribution from the higher order terms in @xmath102 , and neglect the states with the probabilities less than @xmath100 .",
    "suppose , that @xmath129 and @xmath130 . in this case , each pulse generates only one unwanted state from the ground state .",
    "then , only @xmath131 unwanted states will be generated with probabilities ( with the accuracy up to @xmath132 ) @xmath102 , @xmath117 , @xmath133 , ",

    "in this situation one should take into account states with the probabilities up to @xmath132 .",
    "each of these states is generated as a result of two successive non - resonant processes .",
    "however , since the ground state generates only unwanted states with the probabilities of order @xmath102 , the total probability of unwanted states will be given again by eq .",

    "one can see that formula ( [ epsilon ] ) correctly describes the behavior of the system for large value of @xmath102 . when @xmath1 becomes large enough",
    ", one should also include into consideration in eq .",
    "( [ epsilon ] ) the terms of order @xmath154 .",
    "the probabilities of unwanted states are shown in figs .",
    "4  ( a ) and ( b ) in two different scales .",
    "two types of states are clearly seen .",
    "the states in fig .",
    "4 ( a ) are generated as a result of one non - resonant transition , so the probabilities of these states are proportional to @xmath102 .",
    "on the other hand , the states in fig .",
    "4 ( b ) are generated by two successive non - resonant transitions , and they have the probabilities of the order @xmath132 .",
    "we have demonstrated how one can simulate a simple logic operation for a large number of qubits .",
    "we analyzed the probability of correlated errors in the implementation of a cn gate between remote qubits in a spin chain with a large number of qubits . in the limit",
    "when the rabi frequency @xmath104 is much less than the difference between the nmr frequencies of neighboring spins , it is shown that the probability of error , @xmath155 , is mainly defined by the small parameter @xmath102 defined by ( 5 ) and by the number of qubits in the spin chain .",
    "it is demonstrated that at definite values of @xmath104 the value of @xmath102 is small and there is no correlated error in the implementation of the cn gate .",
    "the total probability of unwanted states at other values of @xmath102 is estimated analytically and computed numerically .",
    "since the hamiltonian of the system only allows transitions between the states connected by a single spin transformation , and because the electromagnetic field interacts resonantly only with one spin in the spin chain , the probability of error can not accumulate in a definite single unwanted state .",
    "the probability of each unwanted state is always less than the value of the small parameter of the problem @xmath106",
    ". the considered approach can be useful for experimental testing of scalable solid - state quantum computers .",
    "kane , nature , * 393 * , 133 ( 1998 ) .",
    "r. vrijen , e. yablonovitch , k. wang , h.w .",
    "jiang , a. balandin , v. roychowdhury , t. mor , and d. divincenzo , phys .",
    "a * 62 * , 012306 ( 2000 ) .",
    "berman , g.d .",
    "doolen , p.c .",
    "hammel , and v.i .",
    "tsifrinovich , phys .",
    "b * 61 * , 14694 ( 2000 ) .",
    "berman , g. d. doolen , g. v. lpez , and v. i. tsifrinovich , phys .",
    "a * 61 * , 062305 ( 2000 ) .",
    "berman , g. d. doolen , r. mainieri , and v. i. tsifrinovich , _ introduction to quantum computers _",
    "( world scientific , singapore , 1998 ) ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we discuss how to simulate simple quantum logic operations with a large number of qubits . </S>",
    "<S> these simulations are needed for experimental testing of scalable solid - state quantum computers . quantum logic for remote qubits </S>",
    "<S> is simulated in a spin chain . </S>",
    "<S> analytical estimates are presented for possible correlated errors caused by non - resonant transitions . </S>",
    "<S> a range of parameters is given in which non - resonant effects can be minimized . </S>"
  ]
}
